Award.AwardTitle: Meeting: Linking and uniting micro and macroevolution; September, 2016, Santa Barbara, CA
Award.AbstractNarration:
Evolutionary biologists have identified changes in the rates of speciation and extinction as factors that give rise to the strikingly disparate patterns of species richness across the tree of life. For example, the diversity of the 2000+ species of cichlid fishes is due, in part, to shifts in the rate of speciation within several groups of African and south American lineages, but there are other parts of the tree of life (e.g., coelacanth fishes) that have remained virtually unchanged for millions of years. The success in characterizing the tempo of species diversification reflects the growth of phylogenetic comparative biology over the last twenty years. Despite this success, important questions remain regarding the population-level mechanisms that give rise to unequal speciation and extinction rates. This workshop will bring together biologists with expertise across a range of evolutionary and ecological disciplines to develop new perspectives on how species diversity patterns have evolved across vast temporal and spatial scales. Scientists will synthesize current ideas about how population level processes might scale up to produce species richness patterns and identify new research directions for understanding how speciation, reproductive isolation, and persistence of populations influence biodiversity patterns. New synthesis in this area is necessary to spur the development of new theory that better connects branches of biology that have largely worked independently of one another. The work will provide important insight into understanding past evolution but will also provide tools to understanding the future of life.

This proposal will support a workshop focused on identifying the major gaps that exist in our understanding of the microevolutionary processes that underlie biodiversity patterns at phylogenetic scales. The major product of this workshop will be a review that both articulates major questions that need to be answered to advance macroevolutionary study and identifies fruitful avenues forward for answering these questions. This review will help to advance research at the interface of comparative biology, population biology, speciation, metapopulation dynamics, evolved, and paleobiology. Workshop participants will span early, mid- and late career scientists and includes strong representation of female scientists. This proposal will provide training to two graduate students who will assist with the organization of the meeting and the development of the draft manuscript.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last 20 years the fields of phylogenetic and comparative biology have greatly expanded our understanding of how biodiversity has evolved on the planet. However, despite a surge of interest in dynamics surrounding speciation and extinction of extant lineages based upon molecular phylogenies, a wide gap exists between phylogenetic models of diversification and microevolutionary models of speciation. This disconnect between biologists studying microevolution and macroevolution has resulted in patterns that are difficult to reconcile. As an example, stickleback fishes provide one of the most compelling cases of rapid ecological speciation and have provided enormous insight into the processes surrounding ecological adaptive radiation. However, this capacity generate divergent ectomorphs on the scale of thousands of years has left no footprint at deeper timescales. The family containing stickleback, Gasterosteidae, is not exceptionally species rich compared to other fish families and the lineages diversification rates are unexceptional. Similar decouplings between population-level measures of divergence and phylogenetic speciation rates have been noted in many groups including birds and fruit flies.

 

We proposed this meeting to bring experts from various fields of ecology an evolutionary biology together with the goal of synthesizing current perspectives and outlining new research directions. However, over the course of this award period one of the PIs experiences a major life event that significantly impacted the PIs ability to organize and schedule this meeting. As a result we were unable to hold the meeting and have no outcomes to report. We still believe this is an important topic and are exploring avenues for pursuing the goals of the original proposal.
